results.title: Ukrainian dance
results.creator_credit: Laura Boulton and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Music and dances are performed by the Ukrainian Canadians of Manitoba, largest Slavonic group in Canada. The first part of the film shows the customs and religious ceremonies at holidays for these people. Four dances comprise the second part of the film: the Bird Dance, the Cossack Dance, the Cossack War Dance, and the Catherina Dance.

results.title: Painting and the public: patronage, museums and the art market
results.creator_credit: Judith Wechsler, Linda Zuck, Channel 4, Illuminations Films and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
The way we see works of art, and therefore value them is one of the key changing constants of art. This program looks at the history of the economics and the exhibition of art from the Renaissance to the present, beginning with the great Renaissance patrons, including the Medicis and the Popes, through the royal collections of France, the development of art museums and the current chaos of the art market.

results.title: The Artist and the nude
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
The human body has been the most persistent theme in art. Sinners and saints, children and old men and, of course, women, have all appeared nude in art over the centuries. The nude has been used both as a vehicle for competing ideals of beauty and to portray independent visions of reality. This program details the nude’s changing roles in art and examines why this popular form, though closest to home is hardest to master.

results.title: Abstraction
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
20th century art has been dominated by Abstraction which could be said to be its legacy to art. This program traces the antecedents of Abstraction in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, and then goes on to explore the work of notable Abstractionists, such as Miro, Kandinsky, Mondrian, Barnett Newman, Pollock, Rothko, and Frank Stella, stressing the risk taking aspects of this form of art, and dividing it into two main strands - the geometric and analytic, and that inspired by organic life.

results.title: Ugetsu Monogatari = Tales of the pale and silvery moon after the rain
results.creator_credit: Kenji Mizoguchi, Masaichi Nagata and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: An unforgettably haunting film in every sense, this film is adapted from two stories in a collection of ghostly tales by the eighteenth-century writer Akinari Ueda, and Guy De Maupassant. Genjuro, a poor potter trying to make a living in a war-torn medieval village, is lured away from his devoted wife and young son by the mysterious Lady Wasaka who turns out to be a ghost. When Genjuro returns home repentant, his wife, too, has become a ghost after being murdered by stragglers weary from battle. Mizoguchi’s depiction of the past is vivid, richly detailed but not in the least romantic. For all its panache, the age he shows us is one of cruelty, oppression, and often appalling casual brutality. Cast includes Masayuki Mori, Kinuyo Tanaka and Machiko Kyo. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Ubu Roi Ou les Polonais
results.brief_description:
Alfred Jarry’s Ubu roi (‘King Ubu’) was produced in 1896, with nonrealistic settings and costumes. All the scene settings were displayed simultaneously on a backdrop, and the costumes and makeup were deliberately grotesque, as was the acting style, an amalgam of buffoonery, the horror of Grand Guignol, and extravagant mock-tragedy. Far from posing an alternative to the materialist values of the bourgeois audience, the first line of Ubu roi attacked the audience’s values head on. When Firmin Gemier, in the title role, advanced to face the audience, looked directly into their eyes, and uttered the first scandalous word of the text, ‘merde’ (‘excrement’), a pattern was set that has been followed by many avant-garde theatre companies throughout the 20th century. Reference: Encyclopedia Britanica Online. http://members.eb.com/bol/topic?eu=118827&sctn=3. Accessed January 3 2000

Credits: Director, Jean-Christophe Averty ; photography, Lucien Billard ; music, Claude Terrasse.
Cast: Jean Bouise, Rosy Varte, Hubert Deschamps, Henri Virlojeux.

results.title: Ubu Films: 1965-1970
results.creator_credit: Aggy Read, Albie Thoms, Clemency Weight, David Perry and Ubu Films
results.brief_description: A compilation of experimental shorts made by members of Australia’s first consciously avant garde filmmaking group formed in Sydney in 1965. ‘Blunderball’ (Albie Thoms, 1966), is a parody of James Bond films; in ‘Man and His World’ (Albie Thoms, 1966) a one second image is stretched to fifty seconds; ‘Puncture’ (David Perry, 1967) was created by punching holes in opaque filmstock; ‘Halftone’ (David Perry, 1966) explores the abstract graphic potential of newspaper photographs; ‘Rita & Dundi’ (Albie Thoms, 1966) is a portrait of two women in inner city Sydney; records a ‘happening’ on four cameras; ‘Bluto’ (Albie Thoms, 1967) is a hand-made scratch film; ‘The Tribulations of Mr Dupont Nomore’ (David Perry, 1967) concerns the escape fantasies of a henpecked husband; in ‘Transition’ (Aggy Read,1967) a blank screen is filled with random lines and shapes; ‘Super Block High’ (Aggy Read,1967) is a hand made film created by incising opaque film stock with a grinding wheel; ‘Moon Virility’ (Albie Thoms, 1967) is a hand-made film with a ‘found’ optical soundtrack; ‘Bolero’ (Albie Thoms, 1967) is a n experiment in visual perception to Ravel’s music; ‘Boobs a Lot’ (Aggy Read, 1968) is a montage of Playboy centrefolds cut to the music of the Fugs; ‘David Perry’ (Albie Thoms, 1968) is a ‘synthetic documentary’ of the artist; ‘Tobias Icarus Age Four’ (Clem Weight, 1968); ‘A Sketch on Abigayl’s Belly’ (David Perry, 1968) is a ‘poetic diary film of Perry’s wife’s pregnancy ; ‘Marinetti’ (Albie Thoms, 1969) is a complex ‘longform’ film inspired by F.T. Marinetti; ‘Infinity Girl’ (Aggy Read, 1969) is a film poem with multiple superimpositions; ‘Album’ (David Perry, 1970) is a montage on the theme of the film-maker’s family album.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aggy Read, Albie Thoms, Clemency Weight, David Perry and Ubu Films

results.title: Canada: Toronto and Niagara Falls
results.creator_credit: Carmen Bourquardez and Hughes Leisure Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel, Travel”.
Visits the museums, malls and churches of Toronto and features what to see as a tourist in this city which mixes the old with the new. A religious group the Mennonites, are encountered and later at Toronto’s own Oktoberfest, we join in with the celebration. Journeying to Stratford, we go backstage at the Festival Theatre. The spectacular Niagara Falls and some of the neighbouring attractions are also visited on this journey.

results.title: The Painter's world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present
results.brief_description: A six-part series which explores how and why paintings are made. Each program traces the development of a given subject from the Renaisance to the present, showing how artists can act both conventionally within or radically against constants, always responding to existing works and conditions.
results.title_for_label: The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present
